issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

issue.title: Kyber algorithms not found
issue.body:
Hi,
I am new to OQS Openssl but I did use Openssl (release ver. 1.1.1d) to generate out public and private keys with RSA and encrypt/decrypt file with AES-CBC. I tried to use quantum resistance key encapsulation mechanism through Kyber and signature schemes with Dilithium for my project. 
I followed instruction to build openssl with libops and the build seemed OK (version 1.1.1d with many warning in libops library). I got "Algorithm kyber512 not found" error message when generated private key using "genpkey" command.  See attached screen capture.  
Below is the steps I used on my computer, ubuntu 18.04.
1. sudo apt install cmake gcc libtool libssl-dev make ninja-build unzip xsltproc
2.  git clone --branch OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl.git Qopenssl
3. git clone --branch master https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs.git
cd liboqs
mkdir build && cd build
cmake -GNinja -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/home/test/Qopenssl/oqs ..
ninja
ninja install
4.  ./Configure no-shared linux-x86_64 -lm
make -j

Please assist.
Thanks,
Raymond 
![Kyber512-not-found](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47870738/75815219-dffa3780-5d47-11ea-8542-49a003b2644f.png)

comment.body:
@RLuuPOC The Crystal Kyber proposal is used for both a KEM scheme and a signature scheme; take a look at the Crystal-Kyber in the arxiv as well as the NIST submission paper on Crystal-Kyber [ [https://pq-crystals.org/](https://pq-crystals.org) ]. The KEM is widely refered to as "kyber" although the ``dilithium`` set of signatures are also based on the Crystal-Kyber Mathematical construction as well; it is just not obvious from the name.

As for the instructions, they do work. I have tested them, for the Crystal-Kyber based signature scheme just give it the right name and it will generate them:

```
./apps/openssl req -x509 -new -newkey dilithium2 -keyout d2_CA.key -out d2_CA.crt
./apps/openssl req -x509 -new -newkey dilithium3 -keyout d3_CA.key -out d3_CA.crt
./apps/openssl req -x509 -new -newkey dilithium4 -keyout d4_CA.key -out d4_CA.crt
```

issue.title: Kyber algorithms not found
issue.body:
Hi,
I am new to OQS Openssl but I did use Openssl (release ver. 1.1.1d) to generate out public and private keys with RSA and encrypt/decrypt file with AES-CBC. I tried to use quantum resistance key encapsulation mechanism through Kyber and signature schemes with Dilithium for my project. 
I followed instruction to build openssl with libops and the build seemed OK (version 1.1.1d with many warning in libops library). I got "Algorithm kyber512 not found" error message when generated private key using "genpkey" command.  See attached screen capture.  
Below is the steps I used on my computer, ubuntu 18.04.
1. sudo apt install cmake gcc libtool libssl-dev make ninja-build unzip xsltproc
2.  git clone --branch OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl.git Qopenssl
3. git clone --branch master https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs.git
cd liboqs
mkdir build && cd build
cmake -GNinja -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/home/test/Qopenssl/oqs ..
ninja
ninja install
4.  ./Configure no-shared linux-x86_64 -lm
make -j

Please assist.
Thanks,
Raymond 
![Kyber512-not-found](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47870738/75815219-dffa3780-5d47-11ea-8542-49a003b2644f.png)

comment.body:
@RLuuPOC @ReverseControl [This](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl#supported-algorithms) defines KEM+SIGs for OQS-openssl. "[Crystals](https://pq-crystals.org/)" is the "family name" for

> Kyber, an IND-CCA2-secure key-encapsulation mechanism (KEM); and Dilithium, a strongly EUF-CMA-secure digital signature algorithm

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

comment.body: @gadoofou87 On second thought, I possibly have to retract parts of my statement above: `liboqs` building _will_ (need to) be interdependent with `cpu_features` build: If `liboqs` is build as a shared lib, so will (need to be) `cpu_features` (as we intend to use it internally to select which algorithm variant to run (generic C vs e.g., AVX2-optimized code),right? --> From your experience, (how) does `ExternalProject_Add` cater to this use case (going beyond the compile-time feature detection that this PR addresses)?

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

comment.body:
Updated PR. Returned detection of FMA4 and SSE4A, as support in cpu_features is added. cpu_features now inherits parameter BUILD_SHARED_LIBS.

It also looks like there is a bug on Windows with the build of optimized version of Keccak which is not related to this PR.
```
FAILED: src/CMakeFiles/oqs.dir/common/sha3/sha3x4.c.obj 
C:\PROGRA~2\MICROS~1\2019\COMMUN~1\VC\Tools\MSVC\1424~1.283\bin\Hostx64\x64\cl.exe  /nologo -Doqs_EXPORTS -Iinclude /DWIN32 /D_WINDOWS /W3 /showIncludes /Fosrc\CMakeFiles\oqs.dir\common\sha3\sha3x4.c.obj /Fdsrc\CMakeFiles\oqs.dir\ /FS -c ..\src\common\sha3\sha3x4.c
..\src\common\sha3\sha3x4.c(23): warning C4244: '=': conversion from 'uint64_t' to 'uint8_t', possible loss of data
C:\projects\liboqs\src\common\sha3\keccak4x/KeccakP-1600-times4-SIMD256.c(423): error C2440: 'type cast': cannot convert from '__m256d' to 'V256'
C:\projects\liboqs\src\common\sha3\keccak4x/KeccakP-1600-times4-SIMD256.c(423): error C2168: '_mm256_xor_si256': too few actual parameters for intrinsic function
```

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

comment.body: @gadoofou87 Perfect & Thank you again! I'm now all in favour of accepting this PR and ask @xvzcf for final review.

issue.title: followed liboqs refactoring
issue.body: Following the liboqs cmake refactoring (incl. default build w/o optimisations), one hack in liboqs-build (in openssl's test-build script) became unnecessary, so is removed. Also, the presence of the compile-time define `OQS_COMPILE_CFLAGS` is now considered optional. @xvzcf : If you could consider adding this back in, that'd be great: I used it to inform `openssl speed` users of the compile time options passed not just to openssl but also of those to liboqs -- which arguably has the biggest impact on speed/performance.

comment.body: Instead of the entire CFLAGS list, would it be possible to just report the liboqs build type? That would still give the users an idea of how fast liboqs is.

issue.title: followed liboqs refactoring
issue.body: Following the liboqs cmake refactoring (incl. default build w/o optimisations), one hack in liboqs-build (in openssl's test-build script) became unnecessary, so is removed. Also, the presence of the compile-time define `OQS_COMPILE_CFLAGS` is now considered optional. @xvzcf : If you could consider adding this back in, that'd be great: I used it to inform `openssl speed` users of the compile time options passed not just to openssl but also of those to liboqs -- which arguably has the biggest impact on speed/performance.

comment.body: I thought of this -- but given the build type might mean different things over time, one would need to add a git version to find out what that build type at that moment meant -- assuming only checked-in build types are used and the reader follows this indirection :-( All told, I'd think only the list of CFLAGS are telling the clear truth of how the lib has been built... Let's "park" this until we have more clarity on how we do runtime feature detection: Maybe that is truly all we want to report...

issue.title: followed liboqs refactoring
issue.body: Following the liboqs cmake refactoring (incl. default build w/o optimisations), one hack in liboqs-build (in openssl's test-build script) became unnecessary, so is removed. Also, the presence of the compile-time define `OQS_COMPILE_CFLAGS` is now considered optional. @xvzcf : If you could consider adding this back in, that'd be great: I used it to inform `openssl speed` users of the compile time options passed not just to openssl but also of those to liboqs -- which arguably has the biggest impact on speed/performance.

comment.body:
Indeed, broadly speaking, I was thinking that `march=native` would be the only "major" difference between the "Generic" and "Optimized" build types, but that could change in the future. We could also list only the optimization relevant flags.

At any rate, could you prefix your new comments in `crypto/ec/oqs_meth.c` with a `TODO: Revisit this` or some such and I'll merge it in?

comment.body:
> This is recommended, but we cannot use `add_subdirectory` because we need to build `cpu_features` before running `list-cpu-extensions.c`. I also don't understand why we can't use `ExternalProject_Add` if it works correctly?

That is true. Let me think about it a bit more before getting back to you.

issue.title: linker issue

comment.body:
What is your compilation and linking command?

Also, the code above is not at all correct.  You have not properly allocated memory, you have multiple pointers pointing to the same piece of improperly allocated memory, you haven't called keygen.  Please see the example code in the project for an idea of how to properly use the API.

comment.body: It's confusing to change the issue's title, as we are discussing two different issues. The picnic issue on mac was fixed, so we should close this. The rand issue would be better discussed in a different thread.
